sp.p: And we often pay dear for playing the Tyrant,— when a Man of Sence comes to reflect on the baseness of his Slavery we design him, and prudently refuses the weight of our Shackles, how contemptible do we appear when we prostrate our Charms afresh to re-invite his Service;— therefore, Cousin, have a care of playing foul in Love, least you lose your Gamester that has the best Stock and then be oblig'd to play with others upon Tick.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I protest yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This, Madam, was the kindest thing imaginable;— and though you are fair to a Miracle, it may bring in question, whether your Goodness is not of larger extent than your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, you mis-interpret the One, as you mistake the Other.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Sufferings have confirm'd my Judgment;— and had I ten thousand Lives, the force of your Charms would be justify'd by as many Victims.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I am convinc'd you are in no great danger of being sacrific'd to the force of Love; you're not unexperienc'd of a sure way of Prevention.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: None but your self can cure the Wounds you have made.— Nature generally provides the surest Antidote from what caus'd the Infection.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And from the first Principle of Nature, I shall take care of Self-preservation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'T would be Sacrilege in the highest degree to injure her chiefest Work.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: But, Sir, tho you were so Improvident to entertain an unlucky Passion,— I am confident your long absence has by this time procur'd you a good reasonable Indifferency.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Absence, Madam, has had the same effect on my Passion, as the Wind has on Fire;— it extinguishes a faint Flame, but feeds and excites a great one.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And has not your She-volunteer had Power sufficient to abate those Flames?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What She-volunteer?— Hang me if I can imagine what you mean!

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Come, what little bickrings are these betwixt you two Lovers?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Do you know this Hand?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, by my Soul don't I.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: How's this!— but I do:— Lord, was this the business that rais'd your mighty Scruples?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [to Plyant] I beseech you, Madam, the meaning on't?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: That Letter was a Contrivance of your old Aunt Whim's,— she made Mrs. Grace Copy it, and then sent her with it, to her Brother at the Post-Office, to put it in amongst the Foreign Letters.— Let me see, it begins thus;— You would do well, Madam, to entertain no farther thoughts of that dear Man, whose Fatigues I share, and whose Caresses I enjoy, and so forth:— by the same token the Night you receiv'd it, she laid the Blaid-bone of a Shoulder of Mutton under your Pillow, and pump'd you the next day at Dinner for your Dream.— Do you remember this?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And you, Cousin, privy to the Contrivance?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Indeed Mrs. Grace shew'd me the Letter;— but I profess I look'd upon it so frivolous and improbable, that I never minded to acquaint you with it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am sorry, Madam, you so easily entertain thoughts to my prejudice.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: However, Sir, since it does not lie in my power.—

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Nay, now I swear you tell a Ripper;— for to let you know the truth,— it never did lie in her power till this very day; and now she is wholly Mistress of her self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, Madam, where lies tho next Objection?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Well, since as my Cousin Plyant tells you, I am but this day sole disposer of my Person, it's but reasonable I should spend some time under my own Jurisdiction.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith my Service should not diminish but enlarge your Dominion.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I have no mind to be serious now, but will give my Thoughts a loose for the present. Adieu— Come away Cous.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Whatever Circumference they take, ne're doubt, Sir, their centring upon you,— Hark you, we'll be anon upon the Walks.— Adieu, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hey-day,— what can be the meaning of this? If she gets once into the Town-road of Love, I had been much happier to have receiv'd the kind Salutation of a Twelve-pounder long e're now.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: This is only a feint to draw you to Battle.— Well, of a Souldier, I never saw such a timorous whining Lover as you are.— Why did not you take the little Baggage and fling her into a Coach, and away with her, I'm confident you'd please her better than to have her repent her bargain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your prophane Tongue, or I'll cut it out;— what you say, I cou'd do, did I not love her;— nay more, cut any bodie's Throat that interpos'd:— Ravish the Joys she were so nice of, and then abandon her to Despair and Infamy.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Ay, now you talk like a Man of your own Profession.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Such an Action might be the result of Lust; or what were due to a Jilt; but mine's a Flame pure as the vestal Fire, and she as sacred as the pious Saint that attends the Altar:— But this I'll do, I'll pursue her to the utmost, and reach her too if possible.— Numberless are the Toils of Love and War, and whoever expects to succeed in either is requir'd to be indefatigable.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Just upon the stroak of Three;— the Alderman, no doubt, will be here presently; here he comes already.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Oh, art thou there, my trusty Mercury?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I find, Sir, you are punctual to a minute.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: 'Sbud, I am as hot as a pamper'd Prelate,— my Blood beat an alarum in my Veins to give me notice of the time, and away I came, I'dad.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I'll secure you as cool as Clouted Cream e're she has done with you; I'll assure you she's almost inaccessible, had not I the influence of a Relation over her.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Prithee see, see, good boy; 'Sbodlikins I took a Dose of Cantharides this morning, and methinks I am so lusty.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I vow you look as brisk, Mr. Alderman, as though you were but fifteen.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I? Hem— hem— There's Lungs for you— I am as sound as Heart of Oak, boy:— I was a pritty Youth when I was fifteen— nay, I am a very comely handsome old Gentleman now.— Old— not very old neither, a little turn'd my Prime, not much neither— But prithee see, see a little whether she be at leisure, my dear Boy, will you?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Here she comes— Madam, a very worthy acquaintance of mine begs the liberty to kiss your fair Hand.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: I am oblig'd, Sir, to give civil Entertainment to your self; or to any friend of yours, so far as it consists with my honour.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: When you hear me knock, take care to slip him into your Closet.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Madam, as the rising Sun is ador'd by the prostrate Persian, no less Worship and Veneration shall be paid you, by your humble Slave and Vassal Nicholas Whim, Citizen and Alderman of London.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: Vou are very Courtly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Nay hold, you shall have more— Nor has the Rays of your bright Eyes diffus'd their Power with less force, through the Territories of my Heart, than does the Beams of that glorious Planet shed their Influence through the utmost depths of our sublunary World. Hem, hem. This I heard a City-Poet say to my Lady Mayress.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: What makes you so florid, Sir? you might spare your Rhetorick— a more familiar way of Expression suits better with the matter of Love; and I suppose that's your business.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Yes, my sweet Sugar-sops— Love, Love's the dear business— You have hit the mark, you have nick'd it I'dad— and I'll nick you anon— and my Name is Nick— and there will be Nick upon Nick: how do you like that, Lady Bright?— was not that smart and familiar?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: You are a very merry Gentleman, truly.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Pish, this is nothing, my little Pigsny, to what you shall see me do anon— To give you a taste of my familiarity, let me mumble, let me mumble these Pitty-paddy-pods of yours, E-e-e-e— now let me smuggle between my little Biddy's Bubbies, E-e-e-e— Oh how did they caper it, ferk it and jerk it under the green-wood Tree. [Sings and Dances.] O Lawd, O Lawd, I am taken with a strange Dizziness in my Head— Pray, Madam, have you ever a Coach, or a Pallat-bed, where I might repose my self a little.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: Sir, I'll conduct you into my Chamber, and give you some of my Waters.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Thank you, good Lady; thank you, good Lady.— There, there was a Project of mine.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So, there's one noos'd— I shan't be long without the Fellow on thee: To trap these old Buck-fitches, is, I think, a very reasonable piece of Service.— It's so preposterous a thing to see old doating, drivelling Fellows pretend to feats of Love; the thoughts of it chills my blood, and gives me a disrellish to the sweet Sin it self. I protest here comes Sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I am sincerely glad to find you so minutely punctual, Mr. Eager.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir, I should have been erroneous to a degree of stupidity to have disappointed a Person of your Worth and Character; especially in a business of this moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You say well, Sir: It is a matter of great moment— Scowring off the Rust of Nature, and refining our Vital Spirits, from the scum and dross they contract, by cohabiting with the Earthly particles of the Body— By which the Mind may become alleviated, and all its noble faculties operate with greater freedom and vigour.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I vow, Sir Nicholas, you talk very prittily of Wenching.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I understand it in all its Branches, Divisions, and Sub-divisions.— how far it has been encouraged in several of the best-constituted Governments— and how we came to be Priest-driver from the allow'd practice of it.— I have compos'd a little Tract upon that Subject, which I design to get Printed at Amsterdam— It will be of singular use.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It's pitty but the World should be oblig'd with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I have there laid down its Rise, Growth and Progress, and have trac'd it from its very Original; which I find to be very Antient— Wonderfull antient, truly.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I protest, Sir, your Discourse of it almost equals its pleasures.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: But, Mr. Eager, pray one word with you— Is this Lady of any Descent?— has she any pretensions to Coat-armour?— I vow I won'd not Contaminate my self with vulgar Blood for Christendom— I would not touch the Flesh of any under a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, she is a near Relation of mine by my Mother's side, her Name Vesuvia.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Vesuvia! Ods so, of the Old Neopolitan Vesuvians— Let me see, she beareth in a Field-Argent a Furnace Sable, ejecting sulphureous Flames proper.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Her Furnace may have a Neopolitan Heat in it, as far as I know; do you look to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Family of great Antiquity, upon my Honour.— Burning of Brimstone has been of very long dare in the World.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: And is like to continue very long, or else we lie under a great mistake.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Sir, will you please to Supplicate the Lady to admit of my humble Devoirs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: This is her Lodgings, I'll knock and see whether she be at leisure.
So now for my Disguise.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Having, Madam, received Intimation of your Ladiships high Worth, and nobleness of Blood, I look upon my self to be oblig'd in honour to tender you my Offers of displaying your bearing, and searching into your Pedigree.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: What a pritty ingenious way you have found of opening your Intentions, Good Sir Nicholas Purflew.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Lady of transcendent Parts, I dare avow.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: Your Character is so honourable, and your Ingenuity so conspicuous, that I shall be proud of serving you— Within here, in my Chamber, I have my Scutcheon; if you please, you shall go in and see it.

div.stage: [A Noise of Roaring and Singing without.]

sp.speaker: [Bullies without.]
sp.p: Scour, scour, scour; Ferret, ferret the Whores; Bolt, bolt.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: O Lord, what will become of us? some rude drunken fellows are got into the House, slip into my Closet, and I'll deal with 'em as well as I can.

div.stage: [Vesuvia thrusts Sir Nich. into the Closet.
Enter Eager in Disguise, with Bullies.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Here, here's one.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: O, Madam Mynx, are you there?— Where are the rest of your Coneys of this Burrough?— Da— me, we must have every one, one, or you'll have very hot work on't.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: 'Sbud unrig her, uncase her; make the Picture of Fortune of her, and let her shew the Naked truth.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Let us Revel and Roar, the whole World is our Store;
Nay, the Gods shall Club to our Pleasure:
When we Wallow all Night, in an unknown Delight,
Aurora discovers the Treasure.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Let us never Repine, whilst brisk Wenches and Wine,
Make the Brims of our Lives run over;
Leave the How and the What, to the Politick Sot,
And the When, to the Fool of a Lover.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Thus free from all Cares of Taxes and Wars,
We know not the Name of Dull Sorrow;
Ev'ry Purse is our Prey, which we spend in a Day,
And the Devil take Care for to morrow.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: What, is the Brimstone vanish'd?— I'll rummage her Closet for a Bottle of cold Tea.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Da— me, do, and we'll see the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ro— t me so we will, and then stagger to fresh Game.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: ‛ Ounz here's a brace of old Fornicators.

sp.speaker: Bullies.
sp.p: Out with 'em, Out with 'em.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: No, one at a time.— What a pox does your Goatship here?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Kimbaw him, Kimbaw him.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ay, ay; Kimbaw him, Kimbaw him.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: We'll only make you lighter by a stone or two— that's all, get a cleft stick and a sharp knife here.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: [In the Closet.] O— h.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Hold your bellowing, your turn's a coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Why look you, friend, I am a Man of honour— Sir Nicholas Purflew by name, Herald and Antiquary by profession; Therefore out of a just respect to all honour either past, present, or what's to come; I hope you'll regard me with a due Decorum, and desist from any rudeness.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Da— m your Decorum— You have been a Traytor to your own lawfull Spouse, therefore you must be revers'd.

div.stage: The Bullies set him on his Head, and shake all the Money out of his Pockets, which Eager gathers up.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ay, ay; Reverse him, reverse him.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It rains plentifully; this is one of Old Jupiter's show'rs; so in with him: now for the next.

div.stage: [They turn him in, and the Alderman comes skipping out.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, do you see, Gentlemen, I love a Wench, Gentlemen, as well as the best of you, Gentlemen— and believe you are very honest Gentlemen; and make use of this project to get a little Ready— Pray take this Purse I'dad, and I won't grudge you a Groat on't.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: A very reasonable Gentleman.

div.stage: [Eager and the Bullies go off, shaking the Purse, and Singing, Every Purse is our Prey, which, &c. and crying, Scour, scour, scour.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Come Brother Sir Nicholas, the Coast is clear, a couple of very pritty fellows I'dad.— A— h, Brother, this comes of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: O Lawd, O Lawd, I shan't get my Guts in their right place this month— And the fright for my Manhood won't off, I fear, much longer.— This must certainly be an enchanted Castle; those three were Gyant's Cubs, and that Jezebel the Witch, I dare say she had Cloven feet, had we look'd.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Let's make the best of a bad Market; pop into a Coach;— Drive to a Tavern, and drink away Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I heard a great Noise, thought you might be abus'd; and coming to your Rescue, was met in the next Room by some Ruffians, stript as you see, and beat most confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I'dad I began to have but an ill opinion of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I must confess I began to have some Dubitation, that Mr. Eager had not dealt very candidly.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: This I get by being serviceable to my Friends— and now to be Ill thought on sticks worse by me than my Bastinading.— Wrong my Friends?— I'de be drawn Piece-meal first.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Come Eager, we'll take thee along with us, and recompence thee for thy misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: That's the House, Sir, where the two Ladies went in.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Very well, enough, enough:— Go bid my Coachman turn the Coach before the door, and lash the Horses,— and do you Dogs make a noise, that the Ladies may look out of their Windows and see the Splendour of my Equipage:— I would have the Eyes of a Whole street upon the Gaze, as soon as ever I approach it.— Lol, lol; la, ra, la, ra.

div.stage: Enter Sapless hastily, Puffing and Blowing.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Oh, Couzin, ha I found you?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Sapless,— how long have you been in Town?— What a pox makes you in such a heat?

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Why, I was going to see for yo, to know whether yo can os●e me, to find out our John't Baily; I ha been running up tawn and dawn tawn to finden, and one had as good look't Needle in Bottle a Hay, as any body in this tawn.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: What the devil does he say? Da'me if I understand him a syllable— How does my Lady and your pritty Sisters?— When do they come to town?

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: They'r aw weel at whome, thank ye.— T'lasses are aw-ways tawking on you, Couzin— They lov'n you hugeny b'mass.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Don't say Couzin, when you speak to a Person of Quality, but say, Sir— and prithee try to speak intelligibly; Lawd, lawd, what a monster of a thing is a Country Squire— Oh saw, how he stinks of Sweat.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Giss a little Snush.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Ounz how he paws it!— a foot of an Ox would take it out handsomer— 'Od confound him, he has dropt my box.— What the devil have you done, Sir?— there's not another box-full of it in the Universe— I had it from Donna Aurelia Formalitosa, and she had it from Don Antonio Ernesto Steffatito, and he had it out of the King of Spain's own Box.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: A chawnce, a chawnce comes aws wee'l, aws wee'l:

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pray, for the Respect I bear your Family, let me furnish you with a Tutor, that he may cut you out of the Rough, and Polish you a little;— and when you have got your English, and know how to put on your Cloaths, you may be fit to go to the Accademy— Then I'll take care to lay on the finishing stroaks, and make a compleat Gentleman of you.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Yo tawken— 'Sflesh I am a Gentleman enough aw-ready in mine none Country, and I thinken I ought to be thoughten so here; for I ha been faw drunk at Tavern, and have layn all Neet at a Bawdy-house; and they tell'n me yo London Geutlemen do no more.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O abominable! I find thou art beyond the hope of Retrieving.— I' gad here comes the Ladies— away Sapless— vanish, prithee vanish, I would not be seen in the Company of such an Animal for the Universe.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Marry, and yo been thereabouts— I had rather be Coupled to our Joler for a twelve month, than be forc'd to stay with yo for an hour: and so fare you well with a Murrain to you.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Powder me, Powder me, ye Dog.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Purflew and Mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: O Ladies, I seize you here as lawfull Prize— I rule in this Parish of Covent-Garden as Sovereignly by day, as ever Stoaks did by night, and the Beauties of these Precincts contest my power with as little success as the Bullies did his.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Sure Sir, the limits of a Parish are two small to confine your Graces— the Rays of your Charms have an influence that's Universal.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: That's true, Madam; and when ever they contract themselves to give place to a greater Light, it is in your Presence.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Right Mr. Goosandelo still.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Indeed there's little danger of Mr. Goosandelo altering his temper— a harden'd Fop is as irreclaimable as a sottish Drunkard.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: But, Madam, I suppose you are not unacquainted with Sir Nicholas's Resolution.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I don't at all dispute his Intention, Sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Nor scruple his Judgment, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: There was little occasion for its being over-discerning in its Choice of you, Mr. Goosandelo.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: That's true again, Madam.— I vow I pitty some Ladies that I know— this Wedding will mortifie 'em strangely.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: No doubt of it.— Come, Couzin, let's away.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I'll Usher you to your Coach, Ladies.

div.l: Drive on Dull Time, to reach my Waiting Joys,
Moments are Ages in a Lover's Eyes.
div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE Walks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: THese are the Walks— But I see nothing of them yet.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Ne'er doubt their being here anon, Sir.— I question not but she is as intent upon the Matter as your self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sirrah, hunt about, and be as vigilant as a Lynx— You shall meet with me hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: I'll secure you, Sir, my part shan't be wanting— I'll say that for my self, there is ne'er a Puppy-dog in the Kingdom better taught to seek out and find, than I am.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For my life I can't find out the true nature of Woman— not a single motion of their Minds, but seems irregular— their Thoughts and Resolves no sooner bubble up, but they break and are dissipated with the same puff of Air, that first rais'd 'em— the Composure of their Souls is too light and unsuitable for the strength of their Charms; which have power to oppress with a delight, and to enslave with a pleasure, whilst with a secret Joy, we lose our selves, and blindly trace the mazing Labarinths of Love.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: 'Tis no otherwse than I expected— 'Sbud, Sir, you look very charming— with this Presence you have power to kill like Lightning at a distance— 'Tis but clapping your Hat before your face, and taking it away again of a sudden— Flash, if ere a Woman in Christendom would not fall as flat as a Flounder, I'd perish.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: May be so, I now— Ha bien ajusté; let me die, Eager, I think thou do'st not flatter me.

div.stage: [Looking in his Glass, and pruning himself.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Flatter you!— You can't be flatter'd, your Perfections are unspeakable.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I have now put on most of my Graces, in order to the celebrating my Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Why, the Bride can't choose but think she has got a Young God in her Arms.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Gad I am a Violent Fool to make Love to Mortals, paultry flesh and blood— I should reserve my self for Nymphs and Goddesses.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: No doubt they'll come in search of you; if you'll have but patience— Was you ne'er attack't with a Succubus yet?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Succubus, succubus, who's she? Some forreign Princess! is it not?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p:
No Sir, no; they are black-ey'd Ladies of the Royal Blood of Pluto—
when they find a Man that's cast in something more than Humane Mould, you appear to be; they slip gently into his Bed when he's fast a-sleep,— clasp▪ their airy Limbs about him, and so enjoy him in a Dream.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, if those are they I have 'em ev'ry Night;— they harass me off my Legs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: They are very busie when they find out such a compleat, sweet, youthful Person as your self, especially if he's a Lover of Provocatives, such as Shell-fish, Cavere, Eringo-roots, Pistachoo-past, Spanish Chocolate, &c.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: There's the business then, for I violently love all such things;— but, Eager, there's a great bulky Volume of the Law, a Favourite of the Alderman's, hankers after my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I know him, Breviat: Dam him, next time you see him in your Mistresses Company, kick him, he dares not fight:— To my knowledge he's as fraid of a drawn Sword as an Atheist is of Thunder.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Wou'd I were sure of that,— not but that I know it impossible for any Man to supplant my Interest in her; but I wou'd not have her blow'd upon by the breath of such a Bear, and I am so passionate, that I protest I dare scarce trust my self with repairing my own Injuries:— Can'st not get him murther'd for me?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It will be something chargeable if you'll have it done decently.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Decently? No, no, butcher him any how, his foul Carcass does not deserve a jauntee thrust, else I'd do it my self.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: First do you beat him, if he mutters I'll take him to task.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Let me die, Jack Eager, thou'rt a very honest fellow;— prithee accept of this, and stand my Friend; [gives him Money.] thou shalt stay with me:— If he comes, you and I and my Footmen will trounce him, I'gad,— we'll sacrifice him, a Dog, a Rogue, a Son of a Whore.—

— O Lord, here he comes,— don't take any notice of it, for I ben't in a quarrelling temper at present.— Your Servant, good Mr. Breviat,— I must own I never had any esteem for a Man of your Profession till your Worth laid an Embargo on me and my Services.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, trade freely with your Services where you please;— I fear your Stock is so low, that you are not able to fraight for a Passage, were it only to cross Covent-Garden, to give an account how your Complection heightens.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: What, do you intend to be sharp upon me?— if you do, look to your self, for I'll ●serk you with Repartee, I'll promise you.— Eager, this is the Gentleman that's like to carry the great Fortune, Mrs. Purflew.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Twill be impossible if you make Pretensions, Sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I protest every moment, you make fresh Discoveries of your Sence and Judgment.— Let me perish if I han't forgot to be put on my Scented Leather-Shooes.— Gentlemen, a matter of high concern requires my attending upon my self to my own Apartment.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Was there ever such a Fop in Nature?— and yet they tell me, that the Ladies dote on such Fools.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: That the Ladies love Fools is true enough, but they must be Harmless, Credulous, Passive Fools, not such a Self-admiring Fool, as Mr. Goosandelo is, that insists so much on the Theme of his dear self, that he can't afford the fair Sex their share of Worship and Flattery.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: That I believe is very true.

div.stage: Enter Sapless and Vesuvia; Sapless making awkard Love apart.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Then a Country Eldest Brother Fool, goes down very well with a Lady, though she be a Woman of good Sence, such as there's a pattern of [pointing to Sapless] and she will very lovingly take into her Arms his Worship's lump of animated Earth, though the Blockhead's Brains were compos'd of the worst Mud about his Estate.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: But still I apprehend some danger from this Coxcomb Goosandelo.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: When you see him in your Mistresses Company affront him;— Pull him by the Nose; all Women hate a Coward, as much as they do the Man that deals sincerely with their Looks or Conduct;— and I am confident he dare not resent it.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: As sure as that a London Justice go's snacks with Pick-pockets, or that his Clerk gathers Contribution round the Whores Quarters.— Your Man of Dress is ever too nice for a Quarrel,— he has just now own'd that he fears you'll take occasion to fall out with him.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Sbud, I'll do't then. But he has been▪ at Paris, and has learnt how to push Mathematically, and kill by Demonstration.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: If he comes to pushing, let me alone with him. I'gad I am as ready at whipping Men through the Lungs as a Smithfield Cook is at spitting of Pigs at a Bartholomew Fair.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Stick to me, honest Eager, in this Business, and there's a token of Encouragement for you.— I must step to a Gentleman's Chamber, I'll be here again in a moment.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Well, noble Squire, hey for Cheshire, how proceed you with the Lady, ha?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Marry, Maister Eager, we fadgen prattily:— I ha fast hold on her, and I con but keep her:— But they sen in our Country, that he that has holt on a young Woman has got a slippery Eel by the Tail.

div.stage: Sapless holding Vesuvia by the Skirts of her Gown.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Spear her then, Squire, and that will secure her.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: 'Sflesh, and so I wood, on I cou'd but lighten on her on a Sond-bed:— Nea, what sen yo, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: I say, it's very hard for a poor weak Woman to withstand your strong and pressing Importunities.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Do you think you can dispense with a Country-life, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: No doubt I shall be happy with my pritty Squire in any place.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Oh, we han huge merry Folks in Cheshire!— I'se mind my Horses and my Dogs, and yo san take care o'th' Dairy and feeding o'th' Swine;— and then at Night to Bed, to play at high Gaffer hoop, old Lass.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Come, make no bones on't, there's a Spiritual Flesh-broker lives hard by, that will mould you both up into one Mass of Flesh and Blood in a trice.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Mass I'se lead her thither then. [Hawls her by the Tail, and Sings.] Come away, come away; sweet if thou lov'st, come away.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Coll. Bellair, you are come to the Conclusion of a merry Bargain: here's a Couple just going to be Priest-link'd;— you shall see Madam Vesuvia the Honourable Lady Sapless in a little while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay?— Are you the Son of Sir Thomas Sapless of Cheshire, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Yea, b'Mass, I am his Son and Heir too, as God wou'd hea it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Father, Sir, was an honest Gentleman, and a very good Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: So he was of mine, Sir, to die in good time and leave me the Estate.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So,— here's all at an end, I fear;— we shall have that impertinent mischievous thing call'd Honour, spoil this business, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, I must do that piece of Justice to my old Friend, to put a stop to this Affair;— I can't in Honour do otherwise.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I thought so, I'saith,— 'tis time for me to be gone, lest for the sake of his old Friend, he should think fit to break my Bones out of a point of Honour too.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: Pray what do you mean, good Mr. Collonel? do you think with your Flams to make a breach betwixt our true Conjugal Love and Affection?— Don't believe a word he says, Squire.— Sir, you have nothing to do with Mr. Sapless,— he is my lawful Husband already; he has promis'd me, and that's enough;— and I'll have him if all the Law in the Kingdom will get him me, that I will, ye Scarlet Scarecrow, ye tool of Death and Destruction.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your noise, for 'tis to no purpose:— Mr. Sapless, you were upon the brink of Ruine, and going to marry a Doll Common, therefore come along with me,— I'll make you sensible of the piece of service I do you,— and for this time put you into secure Hands.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Marry, and may be yo tel'n me nothing but what's truth, and therefore, as they sen in our Country, Two words a bargain, I'll look before I leap, so I will.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come away, Sir, pray come along with me.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.p: What? do you think to run away with my Husband? I'll have him; I tell you, I'll have have him in spight of you,— ye paultry, filthy Upstart you.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Purflew and mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: It's pleasant being abroad this Evening.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I am glad it draws so near Night, I would willingly be Femme Covert under the lusty Lawyer:— Here he comes, I vow; I find he has follow'd us upon the dry scent.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What are you upon the hunt for, Spark?— Some Vizor-Mask to put Law-Cases to.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I am come, Madam, to retrieve a purloin'd Heart,— I have issu'd out a Writ de Corde Replegiendo, and it is return'd Elongat ' by your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: You make very learned Love, this might take with some old Westminster-Hall Trotter.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I had rather referr my Bus'ness with you, Madam, to the Abby than to the Hall at present.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: That you mayn't be out of your Road, I'll entertain my Cousin here to put in my Plea.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I fear I shall betray your Cause for self-interest, as all Lawyers do;— I must plead guilty, and put in Security for restoring the lost Heart, for which, Sir, I'll be bound body for body.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I can't except against the Bail;— but if I had it under the Lady's Hand and Seal 'twere sufficient.

sp.speaker: Purf▪
sp.p: What, would you be hooking me into Contract?— If you are so mistrustfull before-hand, I may well judge of your Jealousie afterwards;— and so, Mr. Lawyer, you may turn over another leaf, for you'll find nothing to your purpose here, I'll promise you.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: How's this? my Mistress hot upon the Lawyer? I am glad to see that, I faith.— What now, Black-Box, with Broad-Seal of Yellow Wax?— for such seems your Face afixt to your Body when your Gown's on: What receiving Reprimand at the Bar, ha?

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: What make you ask?— thou Composition of persum'd Past work'd up by the Hands of Quack Operators, thou hast nothing of thy own about thee, but thy Sence, that indeed seems thine by making so dull a forc'd Jest, and afterwards explaining it.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Do you think this is very becoming, Gentlemen, before us?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I apprehended this Lawyer had some-how disoblig'd you, Madam, and so look'd upon my self bound in honour to engage on your Ladiship's side.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Sbud I'll venture to affront him.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, if you must engage, let it be for your self.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: My self? so now I have a good subject, Madam, I am—

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, if you once begin to talk of your self, we shall ne're stop your Mouth, therefore you shall hear me handle that Subject concisely:— You are a vain, noisy, empty, insipid—

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Fool.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: How's this, Sir, is it manners thus to take the Fool out of a Lady's Mouth?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I think, Gentlemen, it would be Manners to share your Discourse so, that you might by turns entertain us both.— I han't had a syllable from either of you yet.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: That's because this Body of the Law has interpos'd; I know my self accomplish'd with all the Rules of general Conversation, and have suitable Sayings for all Complections.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I am no stranger, Sir, to your most refin'd way of Discourse.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: You confound me, Madam, with your Encomium, tho I must own the justice of it: Now for you, Madam, [to Purf.] let us look fix'd on each other a while, that I may drink up your Eyes with mine;— and I that look so brillant with my own, how glorious shall I appear with the addition of your Rays?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Still you take care to squeeze in your self;— I believe you would suffer more patiently the loss of your Mistress,— than be depriv'd of that dear Self-Opinion;— and in my Conscience you undergo more hazard of being jilted by your self, than by the most subtle of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: What, Madam, do you design to be severe upon me, but I have bethought my self of a sure way of overpowring you, [Clapping his Hat before his Face, and taking it away again of a sudden:] Flash, flash, I'gad you're fix'd and transfix'd.— What, Lawyer, are you Thunder-struck too?

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: What a pox can you mean by this Foppery and Impertinence?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Come, Couz. let us slip into another Walk, and leave the Blockheads to wrangle by themselves.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: What was that you said, Sir Foppery and Impertinence;— you lye Sir, Foppery in the Face of you, and Impertinence upon your back-side.

div.stage: [Hits him a slap in the Face, and a kick on the Breech.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir? Come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: A Fool, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: The Lye and a Kick, Sir?

div.stage: They often draw their Swords part of the way out, and slip them up again by turns.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Impertinent Fop, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Then no more to be said, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Then no more to be said neither, if that be all; and so farewell till I meet you next.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Fare you well too, if you be so huffish.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I was coming, Sir, with what haste I was able, to prevent mischief, but I find your Prudence has over-ballanc'd your Passion.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I'gad, Sir, we were very near it;— had I drawn an Inch farther, my Sword had been unsheath'd, and then by this time, this spot of Ground had been delug'd with a Crimson Flood.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You keep the Field, I see.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the Enemy fled not being able to make Head against the terrour of my Puissance,— and e're he rallies again I'll pursue and perfect my Conquest.

div.stage: [Exit contrary way to Breviat. Enter Mrs. Purflew and Mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What are become of the Combatants?— We saw the desperate Action through the Hedge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha; they have taken different Routs, I suppose, to prevent meeting again, tho, as far as I see, they may do it safely at any time;— they are certainly acting a Farce, or they are the rankest Cowards upon the face of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: They are very much in earnest, I'll assure you, Sir, and the Prize they contest for, no less a Stake than this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I fear it would be very hazardous for the Lady to trust her Honour under either of their Protections.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I shall take care never to bring my Honour so far in question to need a Champion for its Defence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The most virtuous, Madam, may be subject to Detraction▪

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And a publick Vindication seldom abates the Scandal,— Innocence is the surest Guard and the best Defence against a Reproach.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now your hand is in, pray Madam, give your Reasoning Faculty the liberty of determining what ought to be the recompence of an unsullied Faith, and how long a time is requir'd to be convinc'd of the reality of Pretensions.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: 'Tis easily answer'd, Sir,— if that Faith respects a Reward, it seems to be too selfish, and therefore deserves none;— and if those Pretensions grow faint, and weary, it's a sign they were never real, and therefore ought not to be valu'd.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, I can give you a more satisfactory Answer;— hark ye, a word in your Ear.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I vow, Couzin, the Air grows so very cool, it's time we should be going, come away.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Adieu, Sir,— I know we shan't be long before we see you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Come in disguise, bring a Parson with me and Jocond Mask'd in a Woman's Habit, this exactly agrees with what the Boy said:— Now methinks the ineffable Joys begin to appear in view, a sudden 〈◊〉 shoots
through my Veins;— my Blood moves quick, and my Breast heaves high, as doubting their force to sustain the approching Bliss, my hasty Thoughts anticipate the flowing Pleasures, and leave me all dissolv'd with the power of Apprehension.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Room in the Alderman's and Sir Nich. House.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Well, old trusty Trojan, is all things in order?— has the Canonical Black his proper Post of Darkness?— hast giv'n my Niece the Cautionary Instructions, honest old dry Chops, ha?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Yes, an't please your Honour's Worship, all things are as they should be, and God send the Lawyer be so, all will be well o're, I'gad— I ha shed many a Tear to think on my poor young Mistress to Night, God love her, poor tender Chicken.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Never doubt her, old Sprightly:— I'dad, I'dad, I shall grow as mad as a March Hare to hear the young Hussie squeak.— If I should come Caterwawling into the Garrets to Night amongst the Wenches, be sure thou exercisest thy retentive Faculty, dost hear?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: An't like your Worship, I was never given to twittle twattle.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Don't you babble then, but hold your Clack.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, I'll be as silent as a Mouse in a Cheese.

sp.speaker: Aid.
sp.p: I hear some body a coming, I believe 'tis the Lawyer, I'll go see.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Is every thing in a decent posture, to make an honourable Reception for that true Epitomy of Honour, my spruce Nephew that must be? Alderman Whim smoaks nothing of our Project, I'll vow thou merit'st Coat-Armour for thy Cunning and Secrecy:— What think'st of a Cat Couchant, ods-life thou shalt have one for thee and thy whole Posterity.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Bless your Honour,— ●eckins I am glad at Heart I can serve your Honour's Worship:— I warrant my young Mistress, Lord save my Child, will feel the Cockles of her Heart leap, when she has got that sweet smock-fac'd Gentleman in Bed with her.— I'll go see that all things be done in print to your Honour's liking.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Do so, honest Sprightly.— Here comes old Whim to vent some new-hatch'd Project, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I have been considering of it, Brother,— and find, if the War holds, we must of necessity introduce Poligamy for the supply of Men.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: On my word, Brother, you say well— The Huns, Lombards, Goths and Vandals, had ne'er made so many Southern Incursions, had they not had a plurality of Wives.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: You shall invent Additions of Honour for them that are most dextrons at Propagation, and add to their former Coats, Bulls, Goats, Stone-horses, and Cock-sparrows— I'dad as old as I am, I'll have for my share half a score at least, and strut about, my little Seraglio, the lusty predominant Alderman, Sultan, Whim.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You do well to talk of a Seraglio, for were those ten Wives to go loose, the Neck of the best Town-Bull in the Country would not be able to support your Horns.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: But hark ye Sir Nicholas, my dear Brother and worthy Knight— Let's consider of disposing of our Charge— I'dad if she gets sensible of her own Power, she'll perhaps bob us both in short.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Your Advice, dear Brother, is of great Importance— Here I'll read you a List of our Proposals.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: And I'll give you my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Imprimis, My Lord Grimace promises us Court-preferment.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: He has not Interest there, not so much as to have a Stand-by from the Yeoman-Usher.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Item, My Lord Supple says he'll make his Appearance for us in the Country at the next Elections.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: His Honour is ham-string'd by bowing two ways at once, therefore his Cringes will be of no farther use. But here's the Company a coming, to morrow we'll settle this Matter, and dedicate this Night to Mirth.

div.stage: Enter at one Door Breviat, Goosandelo, Sapless and Eager, at the other Plyant and Jacond Mask'd; soon after Purflew also Mask'd.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: Oh, you Heavens! what, the Ladies in Masquerade!— had we known that, we would have been in Habits too.— I wou'd have been the Great Mogul, Brother of the Stars, and Son of the Sun, and have out-shin'd my Glorious Father himself:— The Lawyer should have been Prestor John of Aethiopia, Mr. Sapless, Garagantua; and honest Jack Eager, Pantagruel.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: It's no matter, the Ladies shall Unmask presently.— Pray Place you selves, Fiddles: Strike up.

div.stage: [The Fiddles flourish. Enter Tipstaff, and Constables.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Hey-day, what's here to do?— What, Sir Nicholas, is your Arcadian Pastoral to be perform'd by Tipstaves and Constables?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: By your leave, Gentlemen, our Bus'ness is with one John Eager, alias Curryman: here's the Gentleman, seize him.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: What, what's the matter? what Process have you against Mr. Eager?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Only a Warrant, Sir, that Charges him with a few small Forgeries, of Bonds, Wills, and Indentures; that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So now must I be clapt up betwixt a pair of Iron-Grates, and squeez'd dry, and then be turn'd loose for new Exploits— That's the main bus'ness I protest, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I'dad I began to believe this Eager was a sort of a Dangerous Spark.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You wou'd not believe me, Brother; for my part, I saw it in his Eyes, and discover'd the Perfidy of his Soul through the Port-holes of his Body.— Now, now stand clear.

div.p: An Entertainment of Singing and Dancing by Sheppards and Satyrs; in the beginning of which, Sprightly slips off, Goosandelo and Jocond at one Door, and Breviate and Plyant at the other, who soon after return again. At the latter End of the Dance, Bellair appears in Disguise.

lg.head: A SONG, in Dialogue, Sung by Mr. Reading and Mrs. Hodgson: Set by Mr. John Eccles.

lg.l: 1 COme, Thyrsis, come; let us our Voices try,
And Charm the Woods with Orphean Melody.
2 This is the Glorious Annual Night,
That first gave fair Corinna Light.
1 The Bright Corinna,
2 Divine Corinna.
1 Corinna, who has Joys in store;
2 Corinna, whom all Eyes adore:
[Both.] Corinna, who, &c.
1 Come, let us of her Graces tell,
Charms that do Themselves excell.
2 Let us softest Notes reherse,
And Sing her Beauties in Immortal Verse.
[Both.] Let us softest, &c.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: We'll all joyn in Chorus, and Eccho her Praise;
Pay our Vows to the Gods, to smile on her Days:
May she ever be Gay, may she ever be Young;
As our Harmony sweet, and as soft as our Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Very well perform'd, the Interlude we'll have after Supper.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Brother, Brother; Pray what Spark is this that looks so big, and struts about at this Rate?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: It may be he is dropt from the Sky, for I know nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: [Leading up Plyant to the Alderman and Sir Nicholas] Gentlemen, I have the Honour to be your Nephew, and humbly beg you will Approve the Choice your Niece has made.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Ay, Niece: Have you been too nimble for us? Come, Brother, since 'tis so, Mr. Breviat is an ingenious worthy Gentleman, let's wish 'em Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ounz, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: [Leading up Jocond.] Ah, ah, ah; Faith, Lawyer, you are a little beside the Point: Gentlemen, your Beautifull Niece has deliver'd her fair Person to me.— Under therefore your benign Aspect, we shall shine the two brightest Glories of this your Hemisphere.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: What a pox is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Brother; Mr. Goosandelo is a Person of Honour and Quality; I think we shall do well to Congratulate the Match.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [Leading up Mrs. Purflew.] Make room here, I lay claim to this Lady, who lately bore the Name of Purflew, and am ready to justifie my Title.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich. & Alderm.
sp.p: Bless us, who's this?

sp.speaker: Purflew
sp.p: [Discovering her self.] I hope, Uncles, the different Measures in each of your Conducts will excuse my Choice of this Gentleman, whom I have made my Husband.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Pray will you all Unmask, that these Riddles may be explain'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [Discovering himself.] My Name is Bellair; it shall be my Care to set a true Value on the Blessing I have obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Coll. Bellair!

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Who have you got, Mr. Breviat? [Plyant discovering her self.] What, my Couzin Plyant!

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: O Lord, what will become of me when I go the Circuit!— Faith I may now go and take a gentle Swing into the other Word, and so finish the Law upon my self.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Don't despair, Sir; now I am yours, I may be allow'd to own my Affections for you, and since Custom deprives our Sex of making Court where we like; when I was assur'd of my Couz Purflew's Pre-ingagement, I took this method, and shall, I hope, by my Duty, procure your Esteem.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: [Jocand discovering himself.] Oh ye Powers above, I have Married a Boy here.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: And Ha, ha, ha, too:— I'gad I'm glad on't, it's a very pritty Boy by my Soul: come to my Arms, my dear little Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Fine doings, I'dad.— Ah, Brother, we are well enough serv'd for being so distrustfull of each other.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Since my Niece has dispos'd of her self— I am glad she has made Choice of you, Sir:— I am not unacquainted with the Family of the Bellairs, and you, Collonel, have added fresh Lawrels to the Deeds of your worthy Ancestors, and have maintain'd an indisputable Character of a Man of Honour.— Come, let's have another Dance, and so in to the Collation.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Come, now to Supper.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then to that grand Regale of Bliss, where famish'd Love may make an insatiate Feast of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What share, Sir, I have of it, is but a just Reward for your faithfull Passion

div.l: They're sordid Flames, that Int'rest do's impart;
Nothing but Love's a Purchase for a Heart.

div.head: EPILOGUE: Spoke by Miss Howard, in Pages Habit.
div.l: I Find I'm forward in my Tender Age,
And shew the Early Manhood of a Page.
I dare already for a Mistress Tilt,
Bully a Bawd, and Kick a Bant'ring Jilt;
Can cheat at Cards, Slur, Strike, or Palm ● Dye,
Break Windows too, with Mid-night Gallantry.
Thus being qualify'd, I need not fear,
To go abroad a Taring Volunteer,
And be a Captain by another Year.
Ladies, look to't, by that time I come back,
I shall have learnt to Manage an Attack;
I'll Court you then in Military Strain,
And, by my Dint of Conduct, Conquest gain:
But e'er I bid adieu, Faith I've a mind
To leave you some good Wishes here behind.
May Virgin ne'er her first Desires baulk,
So fall to feeding upon Coals or Chaulk.
May never Wife any Occasion miss,
To wipe her Lips of Husband's nauseous Kiss.
May no Rich Widow e'er her Kindness smother,
Or spare to pay the Pains of Younger Brother.
May none of either Sex, e'er fail to find,
A Lover constant, or a Mistress kind.
